Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: RFID Surgical Tagging System for Early Detection of Bone Screw Loosening
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is a cost-effective method for preemptively monitoring bone screw loosening. The current medical diagnostic market is dominated by expensive and time-consuming scans and procedures such as X-rays, CT scans, and MRI scans. These scans are costly and strain medical resources causing delays in the delivery of healthcare. The project will explore the commercial feasibility of streamlining the field of medicine, specifically in the diagnosis of bone screw loosening, through implantable diagnostic tools. Given the trend of preventative health care and growing need for healthcare cost reduction, developing a cost-effective method to diagnose bone screw loosening could augment both of these efforts.

This I-Corps project is to ascertain which customer segment would value the improved diagnostic efficiency of the RFID surgical tagging system such that its commercial application could be realized. The RFID surgical tagging system is a novel method to detect bone screw loosening through an implantable tag placed on surgical screws. This system utilizes low-cost components and an intuitive, yet unique design based on previously patented technology. The original patented technology is used to determine the screw status of hardware on large manufacturing equipment such as rockets. The surgical tagging system yields actionable screw status data in a faster and more easily accessible manner compared to current diagnostic measures for bone screw loosening. Based on the above competencies, the RFID surgical tagging system provides a viable alternative to current diagnostic scans. Through the I-Corps cohort, the team will explore and discover which customer segment values this technology in the medical diagnostic market.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Orthoscrews is aimed at developing a non-invasive tagging system which would be able to detect bone screw loosening post-operatively. Bone screw loosening is a pervasive issue in orthopedic surgery. The device would allow physicians to insert screws with accuracy and continuously monitor the status of screw installations reducing patient complications and improving the pitfalls of current imaging techniques. Following funding through the NSF Innovation-Corps program, our team conducted 150+ interviews over a period of 6 months, experienced the merit of the lean launchpad methodology, and gained valuable insights into the needs of our target customer.

 

Faced with the daunting task of entering the medical device market, our team did not know where to start. Guided by the I-Corps teaching team, we explored many different possible points of entry into the field that we identified during the kick-off weekend. We started the program exploring the veterinary market. The I-Corps process took us from interviewing small animal veterinarians in St. Louis to equestrian specialists at Mississippi State School of Veterinary Medicine. Ultimately, we ruled out the veterinary market after attending a veterinary conference where we interacted with many device vendors who relayed that the veterinary market is approximately 10 years behind the medical device market. The x-ray technology that our potential device aimed to augment was not yet widespread or affordable within veterinary medicine and subsequently, we moved onto the human medical device market.

 

In our journey, we had the opportunity to interact with potential customers, partners, competitors, and other members of our ecosystem that we created through the I-Corps didactic sessions. From interviewing surgeons in many subspecialties, we were able to narrow down the needs of our end user, but we were still unsure of our real customer. The hospital purchasing managers we interviewed valued cost saving products that improved patient outcomes. However, their purchase of orthopedic screws was based simply on cost due to the minimal difference in quality between large contract medical device companies. For the remainder of the 5 week I-Corps, program we investigated the possibility of new product aquisitioners at medical device companies as our final customer. These companies produced the screws that we intended to retrofit with our device and had established infrastructure to help bring a new product to market. These medical device companies were in need of new devices that gathered data on the efficacy of their implants and innovative ideas that solved the needs of their customers, physicians. Our device could provide these medical device companies with crucial differentiation from their competitors.

 

Following the 5-week I-Corps program, we continued to explore our ecosystem by revisiting a subspecialty of physicians that we overlooked, joint-replacement surgeons and delineating our path to market. From a previous interview, we were directed toward this new potential avenue when our physician interviewee noted the prevalence of artificial joint infection-associated loosening. This expanded the potential medical device companies we can look to in the future as potential customers and partners.

 

Throughout our I-Corps journey, we learned, failed, recovered, and grew as entrepreneurs. While our process of customer discovery will be continual throughout the lifetime of this idea, we are armed with the skillsets and knowledge to move forward with customer needs at the forefront of our decision making.

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2020
Modified by: Robert Morgan
